questions.neutral: You look like you've seen some things - rough day?

hobby.message: Political literature still your guilty pleasure?
Analog photography still treating you right?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: Yeah. Just a lot happening in the city today.
Needed air, flew my drone for a bit.
Can’t even do that without crossing checkpoints now.
Things feel different since all those broadcasts started.
Rough day, yeah. I usually fly freestyle drones to clear my head.
They started locking down industrial zones after the free zone protests.
Got stopped twice by patrols, doesn’t feel safe out there lately.
Used to be just me and an open sky.
Now I have to check who’s watching.
Honestly, it’s been a lot. I unwind flying FPV drones after work.
Did a few lines through the old railyard tonight—barely anyone out anymore.
Since the Council confessions, they tightened monitoring even in empty areas.
Last week, someone tried to jam my signal, probably Directorate sweeps.
I’m stubborn, so I keep flying, even if it’s not anonymous anymore.
Strange what counts as risk these days.
Long day. Drone flying’s my thing—FPV freestyle, mostly industrial ruins.
Tonight ran into other flyers running analog gear, off-grid.
They were relaying routes for protestors, using our signals as cover.
Tech’s not really neutral now. Even our hobby gets pulled into politics.
Last time, I dodged a patrol sweep by switching bands mid-flight.
Feels like the city’s watching every move lately.
Honestly, flying feels less freeing, but more important.
Drone flying keeps me sane, always has. Not many know I tune my own firmware.
Used to spend hours looping girders, just static hum and adrenaline.
Since the blackout, we rely on hand-passed codes and analog—Halden’s leak changed everything.
Met a few teens last night repurposing our signal paths for protest routes.
Showed them how to mask their telemetry, just in case scans run deeper.
It’s strange—what was escape is now quiet resistance, a way to connect outside control.
Saw my brother’s name tagged near the plant—first time since his audit.
So yeah, my hobby means more, even if none of it’s simple anymore.
hobby_answer: Yeah, mostly. Depends on what you mean by clean.
Not many official patrols—signal jamming's more of an issue now.
Drone battery drains quick with all the interference these days.
I keep it simple. Public spaces only.
Mostly, but patchy coverage since the last Directorate blackout.
Analog feeds are less scrambled, but static makes flying rough.
Patrols avoid the industrial edges, but that could change fast.
Seen more random signals—probably others trying to stay off BCI too.
I just keep my flights short and safe.
FPV routes are clear enough if you know where to look.
Old cement plant's still good. No interference last night.
Signal gets weird after network blackouts, tougher to keep steady.
Saw a couple of new flyers using handwritten route maps.
Feels like everyone's testing boundaries since the big confessions.
For now, yes. Still flying off-grid, mostly at night.
After the Council confessions, lots more people mapping their own safe routes.
Signals are cleaner away from main roads—but some new jammers pop up.
Met a few teens using walkie-talkie mods to coordinate analog flights.
Shared a few tips, helped them avoid BCI-trigger zones.
Feels less like a hobby, more like quiet resistance lately.
Yeah, FPV's still possible, but it changed a lot lately.
Used to fly for the headspace, now it feels like reading the city’s pulse.
Last week, kids were swapping protest maps over analog feeds—helped them tweak signal boosts.
Rumors say Halden coded analog gaps into BCI coverage—on purpose.
Industrial zones are safe, but everyone’s careful after those survivor leaks and blackouts.
Sometimes I spot Directorate sensor vans, but they avoid old fly sites.
I clean my logs by habit, but now it’s more about trust than compliance.
Honestly, flying is how I check if Stenograd still has cracks left.
Miss flying just for fun, but can't ignore what’s happening around us.
